image.altText: A crowd of people search desperately through a collapse building and rubble in the street

items.synopsis: It is unclear why buses arranged to transport Australian citizens from the West Bank have been delayed, while Israel's military says four people killed on the Lebanon border were part of a "terrorist squad". Follow live.

title.children: Buses for Australians evacuating West Bank delayed, IDF says four 'terrorists' killed near Lebanon border

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: King Abdullah II of Jordan says neither Jordan nor Egypt would be willing to accept any Palestinian refugees, urging the humanitarian situation to be dealt with within Gaza and the West Bank. The Jordanian king told reporters earlier this evening: "I think I can quite strongly speak on behalf of not only of Jordan as a nation, but our friends in Egypt: That is a red line … no refugees in Jordan, no refugees in Egypt. "This is a situation of humanitarian intervention that has to be dealt with inside of Gaza and the West Bank, and not to try and push the Palestinian challenge and their future onto other people's shoulders." King Abdullah made the comments at a press conference following a meeting with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin. About one million Palestinians in Gaza may have been displaced from their homes since the beginning of the war, due to air strikes and the order to evacuate the northern part of the enclave, the United Nations said in an update posted earlier. More than 2 million registered Palestinian refugees already live in Jordan, according to United Nations data. ABC with Reuters and AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jordan and Egypt unwiling to accept Palestinian refugees, King Abdullah says

children.content: King Abdullah II of Jordan says neither Jordan nor Egypt would be willing to accept any Palestinian refugees, urging the humanitarian situation to be dealt with within Gaza and the West Bank.
The Jordanian king told reporters earlier this evening:
"I think I can quite strongly speak on behalf of not only of Jordan as a nation, but our friends in Egypt: That is a red line … no refugees in Jordan, no refugees in Egypt.

"This is a situation of humanitarian intervention that has to be dealt with inside of Gaza and the West Bank, and not to try and push the Palestinian challenge and their future onto other people's shoulders."
King Abdullah made the comments at a press conference following a meeting with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin.
About one million Palestinians in Gaza may have been displaced from their homes since the beginning of the war, due to air strikes and the order to evacuate the northern part of the enclave,
the United Nations said in an update posted earlier
More than 2 million registered Palestinian refugees already live in Jordan, according to United Nations data.
ABC with Reuters and AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hamas's head of international relations Dr Basem Naim says the terrorist group's plan was never to target civilians when militants attacked Southern Israel on October 7. "The chief commander of the Al Qassem Brigade, who initiated the operation, he gave clear instructions not to target civilians or not to harm civilians," he told ABC's 7.30. "In the middle of the confrontation, there was some civilians. The clear instruction was not to kill civilians." The Hamas leader also claimed there were no plans to take civilian hostages. "We haven't planned at any moment to take any civilian hostages. The plan was to take on the fight against soldiers and to take some soldiers as hostages." Pressed on whether he was claiming the terrorist group had lost control of its fighters, Dr Naim told 7.30 that others had infiltrated the Hamas operation. You can read the rest of the story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A Hamas leader says there were no plans to target civilians or take hostages

featuredLink.title: Hamas senior leader says there were no plans to target civilians in Israel attack

children.content: Hamas's head of international relations Dr Basem Naim says the terrorist group's plan was never to target civilians when militants attacked Southern Israel on October 7.
"The chief commander of the Al Qassem Brigade, who initiated the operation, he gave clear instructions not to target civilians or not to harm civilians," he told ABC's 7.30.
"In the middle of the confrontation, there was some civilians. The clear instruction was not to kill civilians."
The Hamas leader also claimed there were no plans to take civilian hostages.
"We haven't planned at any moment to take any civilian hostages. The plan was to take on the fight against soldiers and to take some soldiers as hostages."
Pressed on whether he was claiming the terrorist group had lost control of its fighters, Dr Naim told 7.30 that others had infiltrated the Hamas operation.
You can read the rest of the story below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations human rights office says Israel's siege of Gaza and its evacuation order there could amount to the international crime of "forcible transfer of civilians". Ravina Shamdasani, a spokesperson for the UN human rights office, says Israel seems to have made no effort to ensure civilians temporarily evacuated in Gaza were provided with proper accommodation, as well as satisfactory conditions of hygiene, health, safety and nutrition. "We are concerned that this order, combined with the imposition of a complete siege of Gaza, may not be considered as lawful temporary evacuation and would therefore amount to a forcible transfer of civilians in breach of international law," she says. "Those who managed to comply with the Israeli authorities' order to evacuate are now trapped in the south of the Gaza Strip, with scant shelter, fast-depleting food supplies, little or no access to clean water, sanitation, medicine and other basic needs." The term "forcible transfer" describes the forced relocation of civilian populations and it is a crime against humanity punishable by the International Criminal Court (ICC). Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's Gaza evacuation order could amount to crime of 'forcible transfer of civilians,' UN says

children.content: The United Nations human rights office says Israel's siege of Gaza and its evacuation order there could amount to the international crime of
"forcible transfer of civilians".

Ravina Shamdasani, a spokesperson for the UN human rights office, says Israel seems to have made no effort to ensure civilians temporarily evacuated in Gaza were provided with proper accommodation, as well as satisfactory conditions of hygiene, health, safety and nutrition.

"We are concerned that this order, combined with the imposition of a complete siege of Gaza, may not be considered as lawful temporary evacuation and would therefore amount to a forcible transfer of civilians in breach of international law," she says.

"Those who managed to comply with the Israeli authorities' order to evacuate are now trapped in the south of the Gaza Strip, with scant shelter, fast-depleting food supplies, little or no access to clean water, sanitation, medicine and other basic needs."
The term "forcible transfer" describes the forced relocation of civilian populations and it is a crime against humanity punishable by the International Criminal Court (ICC).
Reuters

image.altText: Couple standing on a rocky landscape.
